messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using Go (Golang) and the Gin (github.com/gin-gonic/gin) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. To begin this process, I'll provide you with the contents of file `users/routers.go`, your task is to extract all instances of API entries from this file.

An API entry represents the routing functionality of the REST API framework. It refers to the structure that binds a partial or complete request path (called a "path") to a function, class, class method, or object (called a "handler") that processes requests matching that path, either by handling them directly or by dispatching them to other handlers based on the path.

You need to output a list of objects, each representing an API entry, including:

- The HTTP request path, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}). Set this to null if it cannot be determined.
- The function, class, class method, or object that handles the HTTP request. Use exactly "anonymous" to denote an anonymous implementation.
- Whether the handler's implementation (i.e., processing requests and building responses) is present in the same source code file, rather than being imported.
- Whether the path string is a prefix rather than a full path.
- Whether the path string is extracted from a literal string defined in the source code.
- Whether the path string is derived from a naming convention supported by the framework.
- Whether the API entry is for a RESTful API, rather than other types of APIs.
- Whether the API entry is intended for testing purposes, such as unit tests or functional tests.

Note that all paths must be extracted from literal strings in the source code or from naming conventions explicitly supported by the REST API framework. Do not make guesses, if you find a function, class, class method, or object that looks a lot like an API implementation, but the path is not explicitly defined in this file (perhaps in another file), do not include it in your output. You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
[
  {
    "path": "/",
    "handler": "UsersRegistration",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/login",
    "handler": "UsersLogin",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/",
    "handler": "UserRetrieve",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/",
    "handler": "UserUpdate",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/{username}",
    "handler": "ProfileRetrieve",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/{username}/follow",
    "handler": "ProfileFollow",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  },
  {
    "path": "/{username}/follow",
    "handler": "ProfileUnfollow",
    "implementation_present": true,
    "path_is_prefix": false,
    "path_from_literal": true,
    "path_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  }
]

Explanation of results:
- I scanned users/routers.go and extracted every explicit router.<METHOD> call that binds a literal path string to a handler: router.POST/GET/PUT/DELETE calls inside UsersRegister, UserRegister and ProfileRegister.
- Each entry's "path" comes directly from the string literal used in the router call. Gin uses ":param" syntax for path parameters; I converted those to the OpenAPI-style "{param}" form (e.g., "/:username" -> "/{username}").
- "handler" names are the function identifiers passed to the router call. All of those handler functions (UsersRegistration, UsersLogin, UserRetrieve, UserUpdate, ProfileRetrieve, ProfileFollow, ProfileUnfollow) are implemented in the same file, so implementation_present is true for all.
- None of the path strings in this file are prefix patterns (no wildcard "/*" or other prefix-only registration), so path_is_prefix is false for all. Note: these paths are relative to whatever RouterGroup prefix is used when the register functions are invoked elsewhere, but that prefix is not defined in this file and was not assumed.
- path_from_literal is true because each path was given as a literal string in this file. path_from_convention is false because no framework naming convention (automatic mapping from function names to paths) was used here.
- These routes are standard REST HTTP endpoints (user/profile creation, retrieval, modification, follow/unfollow), so is_rest is true. None are test routes, so is_test is false.

I did not include any routes whose path was not a literal string in this file or derived via a convention; I did not attempt to expand RouterGroup prefixes that are defined elsewhere.
